title.narrative: COVID-19 FARM AFRICA 2016-2023:Integrated approach , G4F and N4D
COVID-19 FARM AFRICA 2016-2023:Integrated approach , G4F and N4D

description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Integrated approach to improve rural livelihood

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Organisationen Farm Afrika har ansökt om medel hos Sida på 56 500 000 SEK för att genomföra projektet "Integrated approach to improving rural livelihoods, empowering communities and partner" i Etiopien.
Projektet syftar till att åstadkomma en förbättrad, effektiv och hållbar metod för klimatsmart, produktivt och lönsamt jordbruk genom att stärka kapaciteten hos män och kvinnor, på lokal och regional nivå samt andra viktiga aktörer inom den privata sektorn. Projektet är speciellt utformat för att stärka projektledningskapaciteten hos genomförandepartners och att främja synergieffekter när det är möjligt. Det åstadkoms genom följande tre sammanhängande komponenter: 1) Kapacitetsutveckling av projektansvariga och partners (UEWCA och dess associerade medlemmar) i utformning och förvaltning av det övergripande projektet, inklusive de olika tekniska, ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga aspekterna av projektets utformning, projektledning, uppföljning och utvärdering, kommunikation och samordning. 2. Strategiskt stöd till viktiga lokala partners (såsom invånarna i respektive region, jordbruksföretag, CBOs och CSOs, lokala och regionala statliga institutioner, mm.) som genomför aktiviteter för att stödja kvinnor i företag, inklusive organisatoriskt kapacitetstöd inom viktiga teknikområden, särskilt klimatsmart jordbruk, värdekedjeutveckling samt mobilisering av lokala samhällsgrupper. 3. Öka ekonomi och klimatresiliens hos småbrukare genom klimatsmart marknadsstyrd produktion av högvärdiga grödor.
Delprojekt 1 och 3 kommer att implementeras av Farm Africa. Delprojekt 2 kommer att implementeras av Union for Ethiopian Women Chariatable Association (UEWCA). Farm Afrika kommer att underteckna avtalet med Sida och därefter betala ut till UEWCA enligt utbetalningsplan. UEWCA betalar ut 70% av medlen till sina associerade medlemmar för genomförande av projektet på gräsrotsnivå.
Med fokus på SNNP (Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region) Regional State i Delprojekt 3 (specifika woredas/distrikt återstår att ta beslut om), sju regionala stater och Addis Ababa City Administration iDelprojekt2, samt i områden där de CSOs verkar som tar del av kapacitetsuppbyggnadsstöd i Delprojekt1.
Projektet löper över fyra år och totala budgeten uppgår till 56 500 000 SEK. Sida är ensam finansiär. Projektets struktur och innehåll har diskuterats och utvecklats i samråd med Ambassaden i Addis. Farm Afrika ansvarar för att genomföra kvalitetssäkring, tekniska system, givarrapportering och korrekt användning av medel, medan UEWCA och dess associerade medlemmar på regional nivå ansvarar för genomförandet av aktiviteter på fältnivå, lägesrapporter och engagerande av statliga partners. Farm Afrika undertecknar avtalet med Sida och genomförandepartner UEWCA; och kommer att vara ansvarig för utbetalning av medel till UEWCA och genom UEWCA till dess associerade medlemmar på regional nivå. Farm Afrika kommer att ansvara för att rapportera projektets måluppfyllelse och resultat enligt den med Sida överenskomna arbetsplanen. Farm Africa är ensam ansvarig för alla åtaganden i avtalet gentemot Sida och kommer att underteckna avtalet med Sida. Innan utbetalning görs med tredje part kommer Farm Afrika också att underteckna ett avtal med UEWCA för utbetalning till dem.
Projektet finansierar personal vid Farm Africas kontor i London/regionala kontoret samt Ethiopia Country Offices och personal på UEWCA. Därutöver finansieras trainings, workshops, pilottester, kommunikationsmaterial, mm. I delprojekt 1 går största delen av budgeten till kapacitetsuppbyggnad och M&E-förstärkning av Farm Afrika och UEWCA. I delprojekt 2 är huvudbudgetposten stöd till UEWCAs projektgenomförande medan delprojekt 3 går till att genomföra CSA (Climate Smart Agriculture)-relaterad verksamhet. Samtliga tre delprojekt har budget för uppföljning och utvärdering.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

title.narrative: FARM AFRICA 2016-2022:Integrated approach, G4F and N4D

description.narrative: The program is composed of four projects/thematic areas designed in a synergistic way. The first thematic area is capacity building which lay ground for successful implementation of the program. The second thematic areas is climate action implemented through promotion of watershed management, agroforesty practices and dissemination of fuel saving stoves and women economic empowerment. The third thematic area focused on enhancing climate smart agriculture through promotion of improved technologies, farming practices and climate informed decisions. The fourth component of the program is aiming at promoting Market led Natural Resources Management to improve the resilience capacity of ecosystem and respective communities. During the reporting period (January 2018-December 2018) the program has been achieved the following major results under each thematic areas: 1. Capacity building. gap assessment and KAP survey was carried out to identify major gaps in the area of project management, leadership, decision making, financial planning and management, monitoring and evaluation, NRM, CSA, market and gender. Based on the gap assessment capacity building trainings have been given to government, implementing partners (CSOs) and Farm Africa staff in the areas of CC and NRM, CSA, gender, M and E, project management, leadership and decision making, financial planning and management, market engagement. A total of 450 (94 women) staff members were trained in the above mentioned thematic areas. As a result, Farm Africa average organizational capacity score in the area of program management and leadership skill increased from 74.9% to 80%. This in turn resulted in improving Farm Africa’s capacity in the areas of documentation and data management, project delivery and budget utilization, provision of timely financial, technical and managerial support to partners which ensures delivery of the program with high quality standards. Similarly the capacity building trainings given to government and implementing partners resulted in increasing the knowledge score from 50.5% to 71% in the area of CSA, market engagement and NRM. These improvements helped partners to deliver the programme activities with improved quality and enabled them to provide effective services to farmers. It also enables social work affiliated organizations like UEWCA and sub grantees to engage and deliver agricultural and NRM projects. In addition regular qualitative data collection and interpretation capacity has been improved. Building Climate Change Resilient Economic Capacity and Environmental protection role of Ethiopian Women through integrated approaches: The project has been promoting various activities that will improve climate resilient economic development of women and men smallholder farmers. During the reporting period, awareness creation training has been given to 126,124 (69,687 women) community members in the areas of climate change, adaptation and mitigation practices by using women discussion groups, mini media, community discussion events, mass media broadcasts, posters and billboards. As a result target communities knowledge on climate change and climate change manifestations increased from 36% to 65%. This has resulted in practicing more than 5 CSA practices per HH so as to mitigate and adapt to climate change effects in their agricultural system. In order to diversify livelihood of the communities different income generating supports have been given to 2,158 beneficiaries. The beneficiaries have been involved in pity trade, poultry, small ruminant, vegetable gardening and animal fattening. As a result an increment of 6% HH income has been observed which contributes to improved food security at HH level.In addition 2,038 energy efficient cooking stoves, 74 bio gas plants and 70 solar panels have been installed. These interventions has reduced household fuelwood demand by half , leading to reduced forest degradation and deforestation and carbon emission. Moreover, these new energy sources will reduce women workload while contributing to improved health condition of the family by reducing indoor pollution. On the other hand rehabilitation of 424.5 hectares of degraded lands in 16 watersheds have been undertaken and different water and soil conservation practices have been done. 40,000 seedlings of different tree species were produced and planted from 12 nurseries. These will contribute to both climate change adaptation and mitigation in various forms such as providing alternative sources of wood product, hence reduce further deforestation and GHG emission; provide income from harvest of grasses and wood products, integrating bee keeping into the rehabilitation process, and improvement in the ecosystem enhance ecosystem services supply such as regulated water flow for domestic and irrigation water uses, for community recreation and the like. Climate Smart Agriculture(CSA): with the aim to improve target HH crop productivity,income and food security through CSA practices, three training manuals on CSA production of pepper, haricot bean and chick pea, were produced and ToT have been given to 60 participants drawn from agricultural offices, cooperative and project staff. 95 demo plots (45 hectare of land) were established to demonstrate improved crop production technologies and allow smallholder farmers to experience CSA practices. A total of 1,595 smallholder farmers have been trained and supported on climate smart agricultural practices at the demo plot sites in every steps of crop growth and management. The establishment of farmer level demonstration plots and the follow up trainings helped the farmers to understand climate smart agricultural techniques, and adoption of the practices. As a result crop yield increased from 12% - 213% and because of this average HH annual income increased by up to 97%. As a show case Mr. Abreham Abema is one of target HHs for haricot bean CSA demonstration and his productivity increased by three folds. He produced one and half tons of Haricot bean from one hectare but previously he produced maximum of half tons. These areas are food insecure areas, so the increase in household income will automatically contribute to food security and strengthens the resilience of households to withstand the impacts of climate shocks. In order to solve the shortage of quality seed supply in the project area 998 (549 female) seed producing and fellow farmers were trained on seed production and post-harvest handling techniques. Out of the total trained farmers, 263 (female 119 were engaged in seed multiplication and harvested 47.5 tones of hot pepper, 93.9tones of haricot bean and 56.55tones of chick pea seed. The seed producer farmers are linked to seed multiplication and marketing union and the union agreed to pay a premium of 15% than the local price and will supply the improved seed to the local community. As a show case Ms. Sadiya Jemal 35, mother of 6 (3 boys and 3 girls), is one of the target household for haricot bean seed multiplication. Previously, she produced 1tone of haricot bean in half hector of land and now she produced one and half tones of haricot bean. According to her, she uses bio fertilizer for the first time. And she has sold 1.1tones for 9,350.00 ETB to the Horisinka Seed Multiplication and Marketing Union PLC. On the other hand 245 village level saving and credit associations (VSLAs) established with 5,333 members (male = 1,928 and female =3,405). So far saved a total of 664,848.00 Birr. Out of the total 5,333 members, 4,356 (male = 1,475 and female =2,881) members were accessed financial service and a total of 426,257 birr were revolved for loan to VSLA group members. Most of the women involved in petty businesses and are earning profit, which helped them to purchase school materials, clothing, and shoes for their children. Others managed to buy farm inputs such as quality seed and fertilizer, hence enhanced their income and food security. As a case in point, Mr. Detemo Enaro, 42, father of 6, is member of DUBEMO VSLA group. He received 2000.00 birr loan with 10% interest for three months and started a local coffee trade. From the coffee trade he make 420 birr profit every week which enables him to cover school material and clothing for his children and also pay land tax as well as save some money for emergency time. Market system development: The aim of the project is to contribute to improved income and food security status of target HHs by developing a market system that works for the poor in a sustainable manner. Accordingly, 7 Agro dealers established (cost shared approach) and functional to supply agricultural inputs. This has shown the involvement of private sectors in agricultural input marketing has immense potential in improving agricultural production and food security. Establishment of two seed multiplication and marketing cooperatives and engagement in seed multiplication of mung bean brought a significant impact in supplying mung bean seed to the community. The two coops have produced 8.65tones of clean mung bean seed and sold for surrounding farmers, other coops, investors and NGOs. In order to support smallholder farmers with irrigation facilities about 478 meters irrigation canals, 4.5-meter height and 18 meter length concert flume, 380 HDPE pipe and 12 meter length irrigation intake structures, 13 meter iron sheet flume, 12 ponds and 504 M3 retaining gabion structures have been constructed in cost shared mechanisms (30% of the cost is shared by the community). As a result, 548 HHs have accessed water for irrigation and able to cultivate 151.1 hectare of land with vegetables and fruits. Access for irrigation water enables farmers to produce three times a year on high value crops and will contribute for an improved livelihood and food security. Mr. Zekay Hassen, beneficiary of irrigation facilities able to earn more than 92,000.00 birr from the sale of vegetable and spice. With the purpose of introducing improved vegetable varieties 67 demo plots have been conducted on hybrid onion and tomato varieties in collaboration with Sirinka agricultural research center. Accordingly farmers are introduced with high yielding varieties (2 fold yield increment compared with local), with longer shelf life (up to 3 months) which can also be produced during rainy season. Farmers are also linked to private sectors who are involved in importing hybrid vegetable seeds. The project has been working for strong coordination and collaboration among all market actors, two B2B meeting and four MSP meetings were conducted on vegetable and Mung bean marketing. As the result of the meeting, 11 producers cooperative and 10 unions from Addis Ababa have made production contractual agreement and a total of 103.8 tones of mung bean, fruit and vegetables have been sold and benefited 896 farmers. Moreover, community land husbandry practices have been undertaken in 54.5 ha of land and 54,792 tree seedlings were planted in 113 ha of land. As a result of the land husbandry practices degraded lands are turned into productive agricultural land which contributed in livelihood improvement of the community. On the other hand though it is not yet finalized the project has been working to produce Sharia compliant financial products so as to ensure financial access to the community. Over all as a result of the above interventions in the market system project resulted in increasing the HH average annual income by 25.4% and average HH annual income doubled from the baseline.The program significantly contributed towards improving lives of the target community of 190,676 (99,268 which is 40% of programme life time target beneficiaries.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
